entry.title: Securing Developer Tools: OneDev Remote Code Execution
entry.summary: We recently discovered several vulnerabilities in OneDev 7.2.9 that allowed attackers to fully compromise a server and even break out of a Docker environment.

entry.title: Interview with a SonarSource Developer
entry.summary: Curious about life as a Developer at SonarSource? Join us as we discuss changes in the world of programming, the importance of Security, and writing code with SonarCloud Backend Developer Claire Villard.

entry.title: Happy Day of the Programmer!
entry.summary: Join us as we celebrate programmers everywhere, and learn why we value the Community.

entry.title: The Power of Clean Code
entry.summary: Clean Code is fundamental to delivering better software. Read more in this post from SonarSource CEO and co-founder, Olivier Gaudin.

entry.title: WordPress Core - Unauthenticated Blind SSRF
entry.summary: Our security researchers were surprised to discover a low-hanging code vulnerability in WordPress Core that we will discuss in this blog post.

entry.title: You’re 3 minutes away from clean Java pull requests!
entry.summary: In this blog, I’m going to demonstrate how you can get started with SonarCloud in less than 3 minutes and ensure all new Java pull requests are clean, every time.

entry.title: Sonar Streamlines the Race to Release
entry.summary: Knowing if your latest release candidate is built with clean code doesn’t have to be a guessing game. With Sonar at your side, you’ll know that every new line, every PR and every build is clean.

entry.title: Securing Developer Tools: Argument Injection in Visual Studio Code
entry.summary: In the third part of our Securing Developer Tools series, we look at a critical vulnerability that affects one of the most popular code editors: Visual Studio Code.

entry.title: Top 3 takeaways from BlackHat USA 2022
entry.summary: Take a look at our top takeaways from BlackHat USA 2022 at Las Vegas in August.

entry.title: SonarQube 9.6 is here!
entry.summary: Check out what’s new in SonarQube 9.6 in this quick video.

entry.title: Security Implications of URL Parsing Differentials
entry.summary: Our security research led to the discovery of a flaw in a popular Apache2 authentication module. We come back on this case of parsing differential and how various languages behave when working with URLs.

entry.title: How Clean Code Practices Help You Retain Your Development Talent
entry.summary: How Clean Code Practices Help You Retain Your Development Talent

entry.title: Disclosing information with a side-channel in Django
entry.summary: We recently found a vulnerability in Django that allows us to disclose sensitive information. Let’s review the root cause, exploiting technique, and patch.

entry.title: A EuroPython Retrospective
entry.summary: Retrospective of EuroPython 2022 -- Dubin, Ireland

entry.title: Remote Code Execution via Prototype Pollution in Blitz.js
entry.summary: We recently discovered a Prototype Pollution vulnerability in Blitz.js leading to Remote Code Execution. Learn about this bug class and how to avoid it in your code!

entry.title: Unrar Path Traversal Vulnerability affects Zimbra Mail
entry.summary: We discovered a vulnerability in Zimbra Enterprise Email that allows an unauthenticated, remote attacker fully take over Zimbra instances via a flaw in unrar.

entry.title: Reflections upon the We Are Developers 2022 World Congress
entry.summary: Reflections upon the We Are Developers 2022 World Congress - Berlin

entry.title: Zimbra Email - Stealing Clear-Text Credentials via Memcache injection
entry.summary: We discovered flaws in Zimbra, an enterprise email solution, that allow attackers to steal credentials of users and gain access to their email accounts.

entry.title: SonarQube 9.5 is here!
entry.summary: Check out what’s new in SonarQube 9.5 in this quick video.

entry.title: Sonar’s analysis performance targets
entry.summary: We've finally defined our own performance goals for analysis - so that we're no longer subjecting ourselves to apples-to-oranges comparisons with tools that may not have the same goals or outcomes. Or too-subjective, personal assessments of how analysis "seems".
